‚ÄúOne day I would be concentrating fully on work  and the next day I‚Äôd be watching my son while trying to work. I started to develop the classic ‚Äòmom guilt‚Äô where I felt like neither my work nor my son was getting the full level of attention I wanted to give.

I had taken my son out of preschool in early March 2020 as everything began closing down. Having him at home full time was a juggling act. His father and I share custody on an unusual schedule where we are both able to see him on alternating days throughout the week. It was a complicated juggling act.

My son would see me frustrated and stressed. And for me  it was disorienting. What does my week look like? What do I need to accomplish today? What did I even do yesterday? It started to feel overwhelming.

It was around this time that Microsoft announced the Pandemic School Closure and Childcare Leave benefit  designed to help parents all over the world balance this tricky new situation.

Working with my manager  we came up with a schedule where I took every other day off. So  on the days that I had with my son  I was 100 percent focused on him. And on the days that I was at work  I was fully present at work.

My son was getting ready for kindergarten to start in the fall  and because of this program  I was able to help him prepare. We had things to look forward to during our time together. There was consistency  instead of me pushing him to the side.

And I could see the change in him  spending quality time with his mom instead of watching TV while I worked.

Microsoft is always generous  but to offer a benefit like this in such a time of uncertainty demonstrates an awareness and empathy that I‚Äôm not sure any other company can match.‚Äù

‚ÄîAndrea P.  program manager  Seattle  US #PeopleOfMicrosoft #MicrosoftLife

‚ÄúUsually when someone talks about a panic attack or an episode  they‚Äôre 100% sure that something is not right with their emotions. For me  it was small things. I wasn't focused. I couldn't concentrate.

I had made the decision to move to Costa Rica from Brazil over two years ago  focusing on my career at Microsoft. At the time  I was very comfortable living alone in a new country. But when the pandemic came  that comfort turned to fear and anxiety.

I felt guilt both professionally and personally. And then I felt guilty for feeling guilty because at the same time  I had a roof above my head. I had food and my health. It became a snowball effect.

Finally  I got up the courage to talk to my manager  and he was very supportive  and told me that Microsoft offered flexibility to where I was able to work during the pandemic. He could see that I really wanted to take advantage of that program and connected me with HR.
